results.title: Australia's platypus
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films and Lex Halliday
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wild Life”.
A young schoolboy visits Healesville Sanctuary and joins its director (and noted Australian naturalist), Mr David Fleay, on a field trip to capture a platypus for a Western Australian sanctuary. During the excursion, details of the mammal’s physical characteristics, feeding habits, and reproduction are explained. David Fleay returns to Healesville and introduces Corrie, the first platypus bred in captivity, and his father Jack. The film shows their freshwater pool, the earthen bank where Corrie’s mother Jill built her nest in late 1943, and the wooded tunnels filled with grass hay where the platypus prefers to sleep. Also provides information on the origins of the platypus, its place in the wildlife of the Australian continent, and measures for its conservation. Recommends the following books: ‘The Platypus’ by Harry Burrel, ‘Furred Animals of Australia’ by Ellis Troughton, and ‘We Breed the Platypus’ by David Fleay. Commentary by David Low. Photography by Harry Malcolm. Sound recording by J. A. Bruce. Editing by Stanley Moore.

results.title: Australia's people and patterns of work
results.creator_credit: Appleseed Productions, Focus Ausio-Visual Services, Mervyn Dober and Greg Shepherd
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Australia at work”.
A four part series examining Australians’ attitudes to work and to changes in the Australian workplace. The first part of this episode examines the history of industry and labour in Australia, as well as looking at the current diversity of occupations and work throughout the country. Australians involved in unpaid labour are interviewed, particularly women working in domestic labour. The second half of the video examines the difficulties and discrimination encountered by women, migrants, Aborigines and the disabled in the labour market.

results.title: Australia's north-west
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Donald Crombie and Oliver Howes
results.brief_description: Provides glimpses of the change taking place in the desert and sparsely settled cattle country of Australia’s north-west. The Ord River Irrigation scheme, new crops, new methods of cattle breeding, the iron ore mining boom, new towns, new people - all these contribute to the expansion of this little known corner of Australia.

results.title: Australia's new north-west. Pt. 2: The Pilbara-Hamersley region
results.brief_description: This program deals with the pastoral and timber industries in the Pilbara area, the development of iron ore mining at Mount Tom Price and the growth of towns and industries as a result. Narrated by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Australia's New North-West. Pt. 1: The Kimberley
results.brief_description: Part one of a two-part series, this film deals with agricultural and pastoral development in the Kimberley region. It illustrates the results of irrigation on pilot areas and also refers to the Flying Doctor Service, the School of the Air, and stock, crop and pasture improvement. Narrated by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Australia's New Faces 1969 Grand Final
results.creator_credit: GTV9 Melbourne, John Proper, Desmond Tester and Peter Faiman
results.brief_description: Out of 328 acts judged throughout 1969 are the 12 finalists. The winner will receive a $5,000 contract with the Nine Network. The winners - The Paul MacKay Sound; the judges - John Laws, Geoff Brook, Tom Miller, Pat London, Jim McKay. Hosted by Terry Dear and Frank Wilson, voice over by Pete Smith and sponsored by Kevin Dennis. Performing Contestants include Paul Mackay Sound and Mike McClellan.
